awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Single Crystal X-ray Diffractometer to Serve as a Regional Resource
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Professor Kraig Wheeler from Whitworth University and colleagues Jamie Manson from Eastern Washington University, Matthew E Cremeens from Gonzaga University and Travis Denton from Eastern Washington University have acquired a single crystal diffractometer. An X-ray diffractometer allows accurate and precise measurements of the full three-dimensional structure of a molecule.  This includes bond distances and angles.  This provides accurate information about the spatial arrangement of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules.  The studies described here impact many areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry.  In one project, the research targets molecules that may serve as quantum magnets.  In a green chemistry approach, catalysts containing iron are being synthesized that can replace other less expensive metals.  Chalcones, materials with biological activity beneficial for anti-inflammation, are being studied.  The diffractometer is used in a collaborative network to train and to provide undergraduate and graduate students with the principles of crystallography.  The following institutions are the main members of the network:  Whitworth University, Gonzaga University, Eastern Illinois University, Oakland University, Knox College, Eastern Washington University, and Washington State University. 
 
The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially impacts studies of molecular recognition profiles of quasiracemic materials. Medicinal-relevant chalcones are being investigated as well as the design of small organic molecules as possible pharmaceutical chaperones. The diffractometer is used in structure analyses of iron catalysts supported by alpha-diimine ligands.  This instrument also serves projects developing near-infrared active materials.  It is used in research to design small molecule inhibitors of cytochrome 450 2A6 that have potential for use in stopping smoking

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This National Science Foundation Major Research Instrumentation (NSF-MRI) award supported the acquisition of a multi-user single-crystal X-ray diffractometer - a Bruker Photon II CPAD D8 Venture diffractometer equipped with both IμS-Cu and IμS-Mo microfocus X-ray sources and an Oxford Cryosystems 800 liquid-nitrogen low-temperature device.  This instrumentation anchors an integrative applied crystallography center located on the campus of Whitworth University in Spokane, WA, open to students and faculty in the Eastern Washington region as well as the greater academic community of small colleges and universities that support rigorous undergraduate programs.  The facility has partnered with more than 20 research groups from institutions across the country on structural investigations.  These structural projects include the study of functional materials, molecular recognition profiles, supramolecular assemblies, biomolecule structures, and synthetic processes producing published peer-reviewed manuscripts and presentations at national/international scientific conferences. 

This crystallographic facility also serves as a valuable resource for the integration of training and research.  Several courses at each of the PI and Co-PIs institutions have developed various teaching units that provide students direct access to the theory and practical aspects of crystallography.  These educational modules range from lecture materials to inquiry-based laboratory experiences, each designed to impact undergraduate and graduate instruction by providing students the benefit of advanced instrumentation.  The facility has also been proactive in training users and others in the scientific community. In June of 2021, Whitworth University hosted a four-day workshop dedicated to providing in-person instruction focused on the methods and processes of single-crystal X-ray crystallography.  This event attracted 21 participants (undergrads, graduate students, and faculty), mainly from the Pacific Northwest.  They participated in hands-on instruction and formal lectures related to crystallographic theory and applications.  Attendees came away from this experience with a deeper understanding of crystal growth processes, data collection methods, structure solution and refinement strategies, and the preparation of publication-quality figures from completed structure files.


Last Modified: 09/29/2021
Modified by: Kraig A Wheeler
